SENT.plain: INTRODUCTION: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time triptorelin has been reported to cause benign intracranial hypertension
CASE PRESENTATION: A 43-year-old Caucasian woman who suffered from chronic menorrhagia was started on triptorelin, a gonadotrophin-releasing hormone analogue
Three days later, she developed gradually worsening headaches accompanied by bilateral visual disturbance
Examination revealed bilateral papilledema and enlarged blind spots on her visual fields
A diagnosis of benign intracranial hypertension was made and confirmed on magnetic resonance imaging

CONCLUSION: We recommend that patients at high risk (women who are overweight and of reproductive age) who are using any gonadotrophin-releasing hormone analogue (for example, triptorelin) should be periodically monitored for the possible development of benign intracranial hypertension
